Acetabular Loosening: The acetabular cup shows signs of loosening, demonstrated by radiolucent lines, migration, or changes at the bone–implant interface.
Dislocation: The prosthetic hip joint has lost congruency, resulting in dislocation of the hip prosthesis with the femoral head displaced out of the acetabular cup.
Fracture: There is discontinuity of the cortical bone surrounding the hip prosthesis with angulation or deformity, indicative of a periprosthetic fracture adjacent to the implant.
Good Place: The hip prosthesis is in an appropriate position with proper alignment and no evidence of loosening, migration, or malposition.
Native Hip: This represents a native hip joint without prosthetic components, demonstrating normal osseous and joint anatomy.
Spacer: A temporary antibiotic spacer is present within the hip joint, typically used during staged revision arthroplasty to maintain space and deliver local antibiotics.
Stem Loosening: The femoral stem demonstrates signs of loosening, including radiolucent lines, subsidence, or migration along the bone–implant interface.
Infection: There is evidence of periprosthetic joint infection, suggested by findings such as irregular osteolysis, periosteal reaction, soft tissue swelling or fluid collections
Wear: Wear debris is present around the prosthetic components, accompanied by adjacent bone resorption or asymmetric joint space narrowing consistent with prosthesis wear and potential osteolysis.
